data.message:
If a game company wants to have a positive image in the gaming community, they need to focus on making games that players will LOVE, not just games that players will BUY. So much focus is on the marketing / sell-through / ARPU / ARPPU these days. However, I bet if you could graph gamerankings scores against the nebulous "how mad are gamers about the Day 1 DLC / microtrans", I bet it correlates perfectly.

When gamers fall in love with a game, they're excited about more of it, and money stops mattering. The big American F2P games show that. People happily pay 8-10 dollars for a SKIN in League of Legends, or a hat in TF2. These are the same gamers that will flip out over a bunch of 5 dollar Day 1 DLC packs for SimCity.

I am not faulting game studios or publishers for going after the money, they just need to balance that against protecting their brand/image. It is that relationship between price and DLC timing against gamer reception that decides your image, though. It seems that publishers see the dollars from LoL and TF2 and ignore the gamer buzz about why gamers love the game so much. /rant
That's why I don't play Space Invaders anymore.

I'm not arguing with his post at all, I think he is very accurate. I enjoyed his part about Valve vs others; I think that happens all the time. I highly expect this next wave of consoles to have lots of gamer rage because they will adopt the EXACT same mechanisms that Steam already does, but doesn't have Steam's brand.

description: The video game industry is just that. An industry. Which means that it exists in a capitalistic world. You know, a free market. A place where you’re welcome to spend your money on whatever you please…...
message:
Microtransactions are not the devil.

There is an ethically murky space with incomplete-ish or weak games being sold at full price with Day 1 DLC that complete them. That's pretty crappy. (I vaguely fear that SimCity might be one of those games. We'll see when the reviews come out.)
